[This issue](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/2237) seems to be related.
@mistercrunch maybe you know something? :)

Here is my Time section: 
![selection_013](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13405635/28780774-97929d0a-7610-11e7-913d-052f6fb96f22.png)
And here is visualization Query:

```
SELECT processed_at AS __timestamp,
       sum(bytes) AS sum__bytes
FROM
  (SELECT bytes,
          processed_at
   FROM bad_ip
   where src="localhost"
     or dst="localhost"
   order by processed_at) AS expr_qry
WHERE processed_at >= '1917-07-31 13:49:56'
  AND processed_at <= '2017-07-31 13:49:56'
GROUP BY processed_at
LIMIT 50000
```
As you can see in my post above, query result contains milliseconds.

I found a way to get the right format.

- I let the double %% to have the right result in the preview.
- Then after validation I edit the datasource to remove the extra '%'.

Now the query looks as expected, but I need to check if its the right now.

Here, can someone that has impala test this?
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/3225

You need to have a module named `superset_config` in your PYTHONPATH, meaning if yo fire up an interpreter and `import superset_config` it should work. In production at Airbnb we drop that file (`superset_config.py`) into a specific folder, and run `export PYTHONPATH=~/thatfolder`. As you fire up your web server you should see something like this:

I feel like it's pretty common practice for application to do this. Shouldn't users have access to their home?

Though I agree that if the user sets a different home for the configs we should just use that.
If someone wants to add support for a `SUPERSET_HOME` env var I'll be happy reviewing the PR

I raised this issue because superset/config.py specifically says:
All configuration in this file can be overridden by providing a superset_config
in your PYTHONPATH
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/text-anchor

I do have a superset_config.py, it's in my PYTHONPATH. I know superset_config.py is being loaded when I do superset runserver.
But that's not the issue, I need it to work when run from Apache via mod_wsgi.
(And yes my virtualenv is being activated from Apache, because otherwise nothing would work at all.)

Seems like this is what this does:
https://www.npmjs.com/package/json-bigint-string
But is it in the Apache user's PYTHONPATH env?

Yes I know about colors.js.
As an example:
for Time-Series Stacked color appears in the json ( see picture above ), but for Line chart it does not, and that is my problem.

Hey, glad to see someone getting Superset to work with Athena! I wonder if Amazon expose the Presto REST API somehow, because it's battle tested using `PyHive` at Airbnb.

The Superset command logs right to stdout by default, so that should show up in the shell. You can use whatever service runner to rotate the logs and such. At Airbnb we have Superset running in Kubernetes and logs make it to Kibana (elasticsearch). It's a pretty neat setup.

But as to making JDBC work idk, hit the json endpoint and see what's happening. Is it just a timeout? More recent versions may expose a better error msg.

We're absolutely not ripping React out of this project, and PReact is not a viable option. So that leaves:
* FB does the right thing and issues a clean BSD license in a timely fashion
* We move this project out of the ASF and into another foundation (Cloud Native perhaps?) that is fine with React
* Move the IP back to Airbnb?

We should have the conversation on the mailing list. In the meantime I'm keeping an eye on https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/10191 and hoping for the best
I just pushed `0.19.0`, mind trying that?

2. Delete the entire `node_modules` directory
3. Re-download all dependencies by `cnpm`

My definition of "making things easier" would not be adding yet another layer of software (gunicorn) between Apache and Superset. Apache and WSGI have been around for many years because they work really well. I suggest that being able to deploy Superset "out of the box" in such systems is worth the effort.

Hacked around this issue for now.
